section.title: Creating the Component with a Page Tag
section.para: Here is a simple example of how the component can be used on a page:
section.programlisting: ... <rich:progressBar value="#{bean.incValue}" enabled="#{bean.enabled}" id="progrs" action="#{bean.action}" > <f:facet name="initial"> <h:outputText value="Process not started"></h:outputText> </f:facet> <f:facet name="complete"> <h:outputText value="Process completed"></h:outputText> </f:facet> <h:outputText value="{value}%" ></h:outputText> </rich:progressBar> ...

section.title: Creating the Component Dynamically Using Java
Details of Usage
section.para: Some processes running with in an application might take some time to complete, therefore in order to indicate for a user the status of the process we recommend you to use <rich:progressBar> component.
The component employs the following facets to display the "initial" and "complete" states of the process:
However, the usage of these facets is optional. If you omit them nothing will be displayed.
The progress bar starts and finishes rendering its state relying on "minValue" (default value â€“ "0") and "maxValue" (default value is "100") parameters relatively. See the following example:
section.programlisting:
... <rich:progressBar value="#{bean.incValue}" enabled="#{bean.enabled}" id="progrs" minValue="50" maxValue="400"> <h:outputText value="{value}%" ></h:outputText> </rich:progressBar>
...
